channel.title: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help
channel.description:
public static final int START_LOCATION_X = xxxx; // start here public static final int START_LOCATION_Y = xxxx; public static final int START_LOCATION = 3; // random coords
I changed the start location and it worked fine but the random coords are not working, everytime I create a new account it always spawns in the exact same spot, I want to make it spawn at a random spot.
Thanks

item.title: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

Blawan:

Meh still didn’t work.

YO

ohokay:

Make sure your server is actually using those variables to set the spawn location and not reading the data from elsewhere.

Because everything that has been given to you will work.

Read full topic
item.source: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help

item.title: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“ohokay, post:14, topic:545999”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=664888.msg4444837#msg4444837 date=1408231819]

Make sure your server is actually using those variables to set the spawn location and not reading the data from elsewhere.

player.absX = Config.START_LOC_X + Operations.random(3);
player.absY = Config.START_LOC_Y + Operations.random(3);

That’ll give you a little grid of tiles where the player can spawn.

I’ve never understood why people never make it more random and use both positive and negative for their “random” teleports like that:

player.absX Config.START_LOC_X + (Misc.random(1) == 0 ? -Misc.random(START_LOCATION) : +Misc.random(START_LOCATION)); player.absY Config.START_LOC_Y + (Misc.random(1) == 0 ? -Misc.random(START_LOCATION) : +Misc.random(START_LOCATION));
^That’s a poor way of demonstrating it, but you get the idea.
[/quote]

That’ll give you a little grid of tiles where the player can spawn.

Providing his starting position is in a decent place, they won’t need to go negative.

It’s just a 3x3 grid.[/quote]
I know it’s just for more ‘randomization’, just a thing I noticed whenever people make teleports like this.

Read full topic
item.source: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help

^That’s a poor way of demonstrating it, but you get the idea.[/quote]

That'll give you a little grid of tiles where the player can spawn.

Providing his starting position is in a decent place, they won’t need to go negative.

It’s just a 3x3 grid.

item.title: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Blawan:

Please explain were I have to add that code?

In your case, you’d replace:

teleportToX = Config.START_LOCATION_X; teleportToY = Config.START_LOCATION_Y;
With the code, but appropriately. (like, not the variables, just the code for where it teleports)

Read full topic

item.title: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help
item.dc:creator: @Blawan Blawan
item.description:
@Blawan wrote:

[quote=“Dan0194, post:11, topic:545999”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=664888.msg4444837#msg4444837 date=1408231819]

Make sure your server is actually using those variables to set the spawn location and not reading the data from elsewhere.

player.absX = Config.START_LOC_X + Operations.random(3);
player.absY = Config.START_LOC_Y + Operations.random(3);

That’ll give you a little grid of tiles where the player can spawn.

I’ve never understood why people never make it more random and use both positive and negative for their “random” teleports like that:

player.absX Config.START_LOC_X + (Misc.random(1) == 0 ? -Misc.random(START_LOCATION) : +Misc.random(START_LOCATION)); player.absY Config.START_LOC_Y + (Misc.random(1) == 0 ? -Misc.random(START_LOCATION) : +Misc.random(START_LOCATION));
^That’s a poor way of demonstrating it, but you get the idea.
[/quote]

If you want to do it like sk8r and avoid the ternary do something like this.

now it could be both negative and positive.[/quote]

Please explain were I have to add that code?

Read full topic

[/quote]
I’ve never understood why people never make it more random and use both positive and negative for their “random” teleports like that:

item.dc:creator: @Blawan Blawan
item.description:
@Blawan wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:9, topic:545999”][quote author=Blawan link=topic=664888.msg4444859#msg4444859 date=1408238356]
So are you saying I need to change the random coords from another file?

I taught that all I have to do is just add this number (3)…

Sorry if it’s a dumb question but I’m still new to do this and thnx for ur time.
[/quote]
Yes. It’ll be in Player.java, there should be a constructor that asks for the _playerId or similar.
It will be in the constructor.[/quote]

I think this is the one you talking about?

teleportToX = Config.START_LOCATION_X; teleportToY = Config.START_LOCATION_Y;

I got this code from player.java

item.title: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help
item.dc:creator: @Blawan Blawan
item.description:
@Blawan wrote:

Make sure your server is actually using those variables to set the spawn location and not reading the data from elsewhere.

Code: Java
player.absX = Config.START_LOC_X + Operations.random(3);
player.absY = Config.START_LOC_Y + Operations.random(3);

That’ll give you a little grid of tiles where the player can spawn.

Where can I find these variables?

I taught that all I have to do is just add this number 3 or any other number and it will work…

Sorry if it’s a dumb question but I’m still new to do this and thnx for ur time.

Read full topic
item.source: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help

item.title: [Pi] Random Coords - Project Instanity - Requesting Help
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

asshole_rule:

that’s a stupid way of doing that… why accuse others of doing it a weird way when urs is just bad

As I said, my demonstration of what I meant was terrible.
My point was, typically, when people make the “random” teleports like this, they always and generate a random positive value instead of a value that could be positive or negative.

Read full topic
